awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Semiconductor-Based EMI Mitigation Architecture for Future Power Electronics Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: CAREER: Semiconductor-Based Electromagnetic Interference Mitigation Architecture for Future Power Electronics Systems

Power electronic converters use switching semiconductor devices to realize various forms of electric energy conversion. High-speed switching operation generates electromagnetic noise interference (EMI) problems in power electronic systems, which can cause system failure and malfunction. Furthermore, no product can be sold unless passing standard EMI qualifications. EMI issues are considered to have high complexity and nonlinearity, with passive EMI filters being the dominating solution to mitigate this problem. These passive filters tend to be bulky, lossy, costly, sensitive to circuit parasitics, and requiring ?error-and-try? design iterations to achieve satisfactory filter performance. Moreover, EMI problem becomes even more serious with the emergence of wide bandgap (WBG) devices as these new devices have much higher di/dt and dv/dt than silicon devices, so traditional passive filters turn out to affect adversely the power density for modern power electronic converters. This proposed project provides a disruptive semiconductor-based active filtering method which could essentially replace passive filtering solutions that have been used for decades. The success of this project will not only significantly improve the power density and efficiency of future power electronic systems, but also changes the design philosophy for EMI mitigation in such systems. The proposed program integrates cutting-edge research with education, and thus, providing a platform to integrate STEM interdisciplinary knowledge together with hands-on activities with the focus on establishing a pipeline of STEM students in electrical engineering from pre-college to graduate level. With the support of the College of Engineering Career Awareness Program (ECAP) at the University of Arkansas, this project will also foster women and underrepresented students participation in this STEM field. Therefore, this program will enhance the infrastructure for next-generation multidisciplinary diversified STEM education aimed at supporting power engineering workforce development. 

Targeting the fundamental EMI problem in modern WBG electronics conversion, the research objectives of this project are to: (1) establish a new semiconductor-based electromagnetic noise mitigation architecture replacing existing passive-dominated filtering systems and achieving very-high power densities, (2) create and demonstrate a family of semiconductor-based filtering solutions suitable for different applications, (3) investigate the so-called high-frequency-EMI-model-based, real-time, noise compensation framework as a more general plug-&-play EMI solution, and (4) develop a guideline for high-density EMI filter integration.  This proposed semiconductor-based EMI mitigation architecture uses active components to ?eliminate? EMI noises at real time, and thus, it can be self-commissioned in various applications. This proposed research is transformative in the sense that it opens a new area of traditional research. The research activity will advance the knowledge of this nonlinear problem not only in the existing power conversion framework, but also across other electrical engineering subfields as well as physics domains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When the Power Electronics Society embraces the benefits of Wide-Bandgap (WBG) power devices and hopes that this new material development will bring us more dense converter units with higher efficiency, the high switching frequency and current/voltage variation in these WBG compact power conversion units create significant Electromagnetic Interference (EMI), thus limiting power density and efficiency improvement using WBG conversion techniques.

This project aimed to develop a robust framework for electromagnetic interference (EMI) modeling and mitigation for next-generation power electronics systems, leveraging semiconductor-based active approaches. Additionally, it focused on enhancing educational infrastructure, workforce development, and outreach activities to advance EMI-related research and industry applications. This project provides a significant contribution to the PI’s career and helps the PI establish a comprehensive power and energy program. 

The primary objective of this project is to systematically study active EMI filters (AEF) from their theoretical foundations to practical implementations. This approach utilizes operational amplifiers and other active circuits to detect electromagnetic noise, synthesize compensatory signals with appropriate frequency, phase, and amplitude adjustments, and subsequently reinject the signal into the system to mitigate the effects of power switching-generated electromagnetic noise. This methodology offers a significant reduction in the size of passive filters and effectively addresses the root cause of electromagnetic interference.

The principal investigator and his team conducted extensive research on various active EMI filter designs, including noise-sensing, noise-processing, active circuit types, and control methods. Their efforts were directed towards enhancing noise cancellation and system stability during both steady-state and dynamic conditions.

Specifically, the team addressed the challenges associated with the application of AEF in AC/DC power conversion systems. They proposed and demonstrated a series of solutions to augment the sensing/cancellation bandwidth, compensate for group delay and phase delay induced by high-frequency noises, and achieve the highest noise attenuation compared to previously reported literature results.

The team’s research encompassed the development and demonstration of novel analog and digital AEF strategies, including analog-twin-based compensation, digital zero-filtering-based compensation. These strategies have demonstrated superior noise attenuation capabilities.

The team’s research framework provides a comprehensive approach to eliminating electromagnetic noise in wideband gate (WBG) converters, spanning the theoretical to practical implementation stages. This framework elucidates the trade-off between noise attenuation, operation bandwidth, and system stability during steady-state and dynamic conditions, particularly in the context of AC/DC conversion systems. Additionally, the framework offers optimization guidance on the impact of layout parasitics on the filter’s performance.

One of the critical factors influencing EMI filter design is accurate broadband modeling and estimation of propagation path impedance. In this project, the PI’s team proposed an advanced wide-frequency model for long-cable connected power electronics systems. This scalable model encompasses impedance information for an extended frequency range, including mutual coupling between cable cords and skin/proximity effects, while simultaneously maintaining simplicity and improved convergence in computational circuit simulations. This model is anticipated to serve as a generalized high-frequency model for dV/dt filters and EMI filter design, as well as their performance prediction. Additionally, it incorporates interfaces to capture features from WBG converters, such as their switching performances and parasitic distributions, and assess their impact on EMI noise behavior. This model can function as a fundamental guideline for high-frequency side-effect prediction in WBG converter system design.

Based on this modeling effort, the research team further developed automatic filter design and EMI prediction software as essential tools to potentially enhance WBG converter design engineering practices.

The research activities in this project also yielded novel findings beyond active EMI filter designs. The team analyzed the EMI spectrum pattern and its corresponding root causes, including power device switching trajectories and noise propagation path impedances. Consequently, they established a method capable of estimating converter parameters utilizing EMI noises. By detecting the variations and changes in EMI noises, the team is able to monitor the variations of converter parameters and parasitics, thereby facilitating power converter system health monitoring.

With the support of this project, the Principal Investigator (PI) has successfully graduated five Ph.D. students. The PI has also published over twenty papers in prestigious journals and peer-reviewed conferences, and has one pending book proposal. Additionally, the project has inspired two intellectual property disclosures. The PI has initiated multiple workforce training and outreach programs with local high schools and community colleges, focusing on offshore wind, high-voltage direct current (HVDC), and marine energy systems. During the project period, the PI has progressed from an assistant professor to a SUNY Empire Innovation professor and is currently leading a groundbreaking power electronics research and education program at SUNY Stony Brook, which comprises over twenty graduate students. This CAREER award has enabled the PI to establish and expand his research and collaboration network, providing a strong foundation for his future endeavors.
